newsitem.title: DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO: Signs of hope in Brazzaville despite shooting.
newsitem.headline: Signs of hope in Brazzaville despite shooting.

text.p: Fresh shooting rocked the battered Congo Republic capital on Sunday, with supporters of President Pascal Lissouba and his predecessor Denis Sassou Nguesso apparently staking out positions ahead of a new truce.
Confusion reigned over when the ceasefire, initialled by the two men at the weekend, would begin.
U.N. special envoy Mohamed Sahnoun, who helped negotiate the truce proposed by Gabon's veteran president, Omar Bongo, said that it would start formally from midnight on Monday.

"The ceasefire is already in place in a sense but we hope it will be fully respected beginning from Tuesday morning," he told the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) from Gabon's capital Libreville, playing down sporadic shooting in the Congo Republic capital Brazzaville.

Lissouba's spokesman Gregoire Lefouba said the truce would begin at midnight on Sunday. He played down Sunday's shelling. "Since it was the last day before the ceasefire both sides appeared to be marking out their positions," he told Reuters.
With plans for a U.N.-sponsored, mainly African peacekeeping force taking shape, Sahnoun said talks would take place in Libreville this week after an initial meeting in Brazzaville.

He predicted talks should be fully under way by Tuesday or Wednesday. "The most important thing is what are the ways and means to have a national reconciliation and to create an environment which will enable us to organise the elections which are due some time over the next two months," he said.

The bloody showdown in the capital of the oil-producing former French colony began on June 5 when soldiers surrounded Sassou's home as part of a crackdown on private militias ahead of a now-postponed June 27 presidential election.
The political and ethnic clashes coupled with indiscriminate shell and rocket fire have killed hundreds of people, many of them civilians, medical workers say.

Diplomatic sources told Reuters across the river in Kinshasa that the only real hope of ensuring a lasting ceasefire would be to persuade heavily-armed rival soldiers and militiamen on barricades across Brazzaville to leave the streets.

Sahnoun, a veteran Algerian diplomat, was in Brazzaville on Thursday for talks with the chief rivals. "I am always very sceptical but I think this will lead to a serious outcome," he told Reuters on Saturday after the two sides had signed.

Sahnoun said on Saturday the militia issue would be dealt with in the talks. He said the warring parties and neighbouring countries wanted a peace force deployed, adding: "It will be an important psychological factor to enhance the peace process."

Lissouba's spokesman Lefouba told Radio France International the government backed a return of peace. "I have faith and have confidence that both sides understand that this is a dirty war that is neither in the interest of the Congolese people nor of those who want to govern the country in future," he added.
Sassou spokesman Francis Iboovi told French radio the nation needed a transition and a national salvation government.
"There is no effective government today so conditions must be created to guarantee the organisation of a fair and honest election."
Lissouba's mandate expires at the end of August. He says the constitution allows a 90-day extension to organise elections.
Lissouba, Sassou and Brazzaville mayor Bernard Kolelas, a national mediator whose militia have kept out of the latest fighting, all planned to contest the July 27 election.
Kolelas's militia was at the heart of similar political and ethnic clashes that killed at least 2,000 people in Brazzaville after a disputed 1993 parliamentary election.
